data.title: Basketball became 'sanctuary' for Montana State's Robert Ford III after deaths of father, brother
data.meta_description: “It doesn’t matter where I'm at, I'm doing this for me and my family. That helps me get by each day.” Robert Ford III
data.text:
BOZEMAN — The story of Robert Ford III can be summarized by his shoes.

Montana State has a shoe and apparel deal that requires its athletes to wear Under Armour gear. Ford III tried various UA and Adidas shoes last men’s basketball season (his first as a Bobcat), but none fortified his injured left foot. When he wore Nike Jordan 10s and KD 3s, the pain went away.

Ford III is allowed to play in those sneakers under one condition: the Nike logo must be covered. So he sticks white tape on both sides of each shoe before every MSU game.

All season long, Ford III has drawn a smiley face on both pieces of tape. He also scribbles his signature on the right shoe, along with three words: “Family,” “Love” and his daughter’s name, Ciara. On the left tape, he writes “Just Business” and three groups of letters. Each line starts with “LL” — short for “long live” — followed by “MR” on the top line, “RF Jr” in the middle and “TM” on the bottom. Those are the initials of Ford III’s brother, father and uncle. All three were killed.

Ford III plays as he’s being propelled by the inscriptions on his shoes. He’s listed at 6 feet but rebounds like a 7-footer. He’s one of the best defensive players in the Big Sky Conference. The former Clackamas (Oregon) Community College and Idaho State standout glides into the lane for tough finishes and passes. He dances around defenders before firing 3-pointers.

Tough moments on the court and the tragedies off it have driven Ford III to become an all-conference caliber player in his final college season. They’ve molded him into a person his remaining family members can be proud of.

“I know they're with me,” Ford III told 406mtsports.com, referring to his brother, father and uncle. “It doesn’t matter where I'm at, I'm doing this for me and my family. That helps me get by each day.”

Dealing with devastation

Ford III's uncle Troy McCollum was murdered in 1995, four years before Ford III was born.

On July 18, 2012, Robert Ford Jr. was fatally shot in Southeast Portland, Oregon. He was 31 years old.

“We lost the person that was the provider and kind of held the family together, so it was really hard, especially for my brother,” said Ford III’s younger brother Alileyon Ford. “He had to kind of pick up and help everybody else.”

On July 27, 2020, Ford III’s younger brother, M.R. Ford, was fatally shot in Northeast Portland. In addition to his three siblings, M.R. was survived by a 2-year-old son. He was 19.

“When you go through things like that, it kind of takes you to a different place,” Ford III said. “You have to regroup.”

Ford III’s father and brother were “great people,” he said. They were always happy, always smiling, always making people laugh.

“Being able to keep that going with my siblings — my little brother and my little sister — that's what brings me good joy,” Ford III added, “keeping everything alive.”

Ford III spent his 21st birthday in the middle of the COVID-19 pandemic. He was in his eighth year without his father, and he had just moved to Pocatello, Idaho, nearly 700 miles away from Portland. For the first time in his life, he couldn't celebrate his birthday with M.R. Both were born on Oct. 25 — Ford III in 1999, M.R. in 2000.

But Oct. 25, 2020, wasn’t entirely gloomy to Ford III. Idaho State men’s basketball practices had begun a couple weeks earlier, and the 2020-21 season opener was exactly one month away.

“Basketball has really been somewhere for me to get away,” Ford III said. “It’s my getaway space, my sanctuary.”

Thriving in the sanctuary

Ford III was the fifth option throughout his career at Jefferson High School in Portland. Until his junior season, which ended with a state championship, Ford III played power forward. He was a good rebounder, and Jefferson had other future Division I guards/wings, such as Marcus Tsohonis, who played with future MSU star RaeQuan Battle at Washington before both transferred.

Ford III averaged about four points per game at Jefferson and received only a few college offers, all from sub-Division II programs. He chose to spend his first two college seasons at Clackamas CC, which is about 20 miles south of Portland. He hoped the junior college would springboard him to a D-I school.

“I always understood my route would never be easy,” Ford III said.

Clackamas CC head coach Clif Wegner knew he was getting an elite defender and a good distributor, and he was right — Ford III averaged 7.8 assists and 2.9 steals per game in his two seasons with the Cougars. Wegner didn’t predict Ford III would average 23.2 points per game at Clackamas, and he couldn’t fathom that Ford III would average 10.5 rebounds per game.

“He might be the best rebounder at that size I've seen in my life,” Wegner said.

Wegner usually tells his point guards not to crash the glass, but Ford III was effective at leading fast breaks no matter how he got the ball. And when he had a chance to grab a rebound, he would not be denied.

“He said, ‘Coach, that rebound’s just too damn important to trust it to the post kids,'” Wegner said with a laugh. “It’s a truly rare gift. It's one of the things that makes him a very special player, the way he rebounds and gets going on a break. It’s like he catches it going downhill.”

In 2020, Ford III chose Idaho State over multiple other D-I programs that recruited him, including MSU. With M.R. in his heart, Ford III started all 24 games in 2020-21 and earned an All-Big Sky honorable mention with averages of 11.4 points, 7.2 rebounds, 3.1 assists and 1.2 steals per game.

A stress fracture in his left foot limited Ford III to nine games in 2021-22. He entered the transfer portal after the season, saying it was simply “the right choice for me and my family.”

MSU added Ford III and Darius Brown II to replace All-Big Sky point guard Xavier Bishop and other 2021-22 ball handlers who didn’t return. With Brown as the starter and Ford III as his backup, the Bobcats won the Big Sky tournament title and reached the NCAA Tournament for the second straight season.

Ford III played 20.8 minutes per game last season but averaged 4.4 points and 3.2 rebounds per game while shooting 28.6% from the field and 26.2% from 3. He made 41.5% of his field goals and 37.6% of his 3s at ISU after a couple of solid shooting seasons at Clackamas CC, so his drop-off at MSU was puzzling.

Ford III’s left foot probably played a role. The stress fracture he suffered in late 2021 hadn’t fully healed, and it capped him at about 80% throughout 2022-23, in his estimation. Brown, who earned the Big Sky defensive player of the year honor, wasn’t fully healthy either, according to then-MSU head coach Danny Sprinkle.

“I give both those two a lot of credit for playing through a lot of injuries and pain,” Sprinkle said in January.

Shortly after Sprinkle left MSU for Utah State last April, Ford III entered the portal. Sprinkle’s successor, Matt Logie, met with Ford III and his family members several times over the next few weeks and convinced Ford III to return.

“My ultimate thing was finding a place that felt like home, that built the best relationship, and Logie did that,” Ford III said. “Coming back was one of the best decisions that I made.”

Thanks in part to his new shoes, Ford III has started all 29 games at point guard this season. He leads the Cats in points per game (15.3) and 3-point percentage (42.5%), with a 46.6% field goal mark and 2.9 assists per game. His 83 steals are second and his 2.86 steals per game are third among all D-I players. He has a chance to break the MSU record for steals in a season (94).

“There's nobody I've ever coached that so explicitly leaves it all out on the floor,” Logie said.

Ford III also averages a team-high 7.8 rebounds per game and has been among the best rebounders under 6-foot-3 in all of D-I men’s basketball this season, per MSU. Effort is the biggest key to his glass aptitude, Logie said. Ford III is also elite at reading where shots will bounce off the rim while they’re in the air.

“He does steal a couple,” MSU forward Sam Lecholat said with a laugh. “He's just a ball magnet. He sees that thing in the air and his vertical is so high and he’s so athletic, he just goes and grabs that thing.”

Ford III has been “highly coachable” since he exited the portal last spring, Logie said, working diligently on his footwork, shooting form, shot selection, ball screen reads and more. Logie has noticed that Ford III often centers himself, usually by taking a few deep breaths, before leaving the timeout huddle.

Ford III’s effort, production and lead-by-example style have helped the Cats stay competitive after they lost their entire coaching staff and four of their five starters last year. MSU is 13-16 overall and 8-8 in Big Sky play — fifth place, one game ahead of ISU — heading into its final two games of the regular season.

“His passion and competitive spirit have infiltrated this basketball team. That's leadership in a nutshell,” Logie said. “His ability to not just bring that fire and passion but also have the mentality and emotional IQ to lead through adversity is really impressive. It’s something I will remember for years beyond his play here at Montana State.”

‘Setting an example’

Alileyon is a sophomore on the Clackamas CC men’s basketball team. He didn’t always plan to follow the same path as his older brother, but Ford III’s influence was unavoidable. Rain or shine, Ford III and Alileyon played hoops almost every day after school.

“My game has definitely taken some notes from his playbook, especially his hustle and his drive to win,” Alileyon said, adding, “He has a dog in him. He just won’t stop. He's like a gnat.”

Alileyon remembers a game-winning shot Ford III missed during a youth tournament. It wasn’t the shot that stood out in Alileyon’s mind; it was Ford III’s reaction.

“He had that demeanor of, like, ‘I won't miss again,’” Alileyon said. “That was the most impactful for me to see: him taking that one and not pouting or nothing like that. He just kept his head high.”

Ford III is reticent to talk about his brother’s and father’s deaths, but he doesn’t hide from the pain. He’s been a supportive son to his mother, Nicole McCollum, and he’s become a father figure to Alileyon and their sister, Sa’myia.

“Taking us under his wing, setting an example, not doing drugs,” Alileyon said. “Just being that person that you can look up to and you can say, ‘This is a great person.’ Even in school, he always tried hard. I always saw him working to get his schoolwork done.”

Whenever Ford III comes home, he spends countless hours in the gym. He’s been that way since Clackamas.

“He had a 30- to 50-minute commute one way every day, and he was always there early, always shooting late,” Wegner said. “He wouldn't take a day off. I had to order him to take a day off.”

Ford III’s work ethic and ability to trudge through tough times has rubbed off on his MSU teammates.

“He's a strong dude. He's really mature for his age,” said MSU guard Eddie Turner III, whose father recently had a health scare. “He's just years ahead of everyone else here. He's a guy that we lean on.”

Ford III wants to honor the memory of his late family members and continue to be a positive influence to Alileyon, Sa’myia and their mother. He’s also focused on being a good father.

Ciara was born five years ago, when Ford III attended Clackamas. She lives with her mother in Portland and has attended some MSU games this season. Ford III talks with her often over FaceTime.

It’s fitting that Ford III writes Ciara’s name on the same shoe as his signature. He’s providing good footsteps for her to follow.

“She's my biggest why,” Ford III said, “why I keep going.”
